lines.text:
[opening a box of candy]
Ah, pecan butternut fudge!
Oh, my, you mustn't eat candy, Mr. Whiteside, it's very bad for you.
My great aunt Jennifer ate a whole box of candy every day of her life. She lived to be 102 and when she'd been dead three days she looked better than you do *now!*

[lasciviously to Nurse Preen]
Come to my room in a half hour and bring some rye bread.
Sherry, the next time you do NOT want to see anybody, just let me know, and I'll usher them right in.
Did you ever have the feeling that you wanted to go, and still have the feeling that you wanted to stay?
I have very little time, and so the conversation will be entirely about me and I shall love it.
Strange? She's right out of The Hound of the Baskervilles.
How do you think Ohio women stack up?
I've never gone in for stacking women up so I really can't say.
And now, will you all now leave quietly, or must I ask Miss Cutler to pass among you with a baseball bat?
You know, Sheridan, you have one great advantage over everyone else in the world. You've never had to meet Sheridan Whiteside.
Go in and read the life of Florence Nightingale and learn how unfitted you are for your chosen profession.
Will you take your clammy hand off my chair? You have the touch of a love-starved cobra.
This ageing debutante, Mr. Jefferson, I retain in my employ only because she is the sole support of her two-headed brother!
I simply will not sit down to dinner with midwestern barbarians, I think too highly of my digestive system.
Harry Clarke is one of your oldest friends.
My stomach is an older one.
And Mrs. Stanley is president of the women's club.
I wouldn't care if she was the whole cabinet.
Is there a man in the world who suffers as I do from the gross inadequacies of the human race?
Sherry, without launching into mountainous waves of self-pity, how are you?

[to Sheridan]
Don't you pull any of your tricks on me, because I'm on to every one of them. So lay off. That's my message to you... "Big" Lord Fauntleroy!

I am not only walking out on this case, Mr. Whiteside, I am leaving the nursing profession. I became a nurse because all my life, ever since I was a little girl, I was filled with the idea of serving a suffering humanity. After one month with you , Mr. Whiteside, I am going to work in a munitions factory. From now on , anything I can do to help exterminate the human race will fill me with the greatest of pleasure. If Florence Nightingale had ever nursed YOU, Mr. Whiteside, she would have married Jack the Ripper instead of founding the Red Cross!
Banjo, my lad, you're wonderful. I may write a book about you.
Don't bother, I can't read!
Get your fish-hooks off me!
I suppose you've written the great American novel.
No, I've written the great American play.
Well I don't want to read it.

[to Nurse Preen]
I can feel the hot blood pounding through your varicose veins.
Mr. Whiteside, I can only be in one place at a time.
That's very fortunate for this community.
How long can you stay?
Just long enough to take a bath.
How can one man possibly be as clever as I am?

[repeated line, most of the times the doctor appears out of a side door just when Whiteside is at the center of a three ring circus of activity]
Mr. Whiteside, are you busy?
Who does your hair, Maggie?
A little French woman named Maggie Cutler comes in every morning.
You know, your hair could be so lovely. I've always wanted to get my hands on it.
I've always wanted to get my hands on yours, Lorraine.
How 'bout a hot sweet potato?
Oh, a sweet potato? That's what they serve at "21" with pineapple glacé.
A penguin bit me!
Mrs. Roosevelt, there's something I want you to know. My husband didn't vote for your husband. But I did.
I shall require the exclusive use of this room, as well as that drafty sewer you call the library. I want no one to come in or out while I am in this room.
But we have to go up those steps to get to our rooms, Mr. Whiteside.
Isn't there a back entrance?
Well, Yes...
Then use that. Let me see, there will be a great many incoming and outgoing calls, so please do not use the telephone.
You know more people than a head waiter.
I've been skating for the first time in my life! I'm told I'm the only person to do a figure eight from the sitting position!
I had to go to three different stores.
How did you travel? By ox cart?
When I finally leave this job, I may write a book about it... Through the years with Prince Charming.
Suppose your parents are unhappy with you. It's good for them. It develops character.
Magpie, my dear, you are the moon flower of my middle age.

[to Mr. Whiteside]
I think you're incapable of any emotion higher up than your stomach!
We are not amused.
